results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 15]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film is comprised of two parts. Firstly, travelling on a road tour through South Gippsland from Wilson’s Promontory to Walhalla, Kenneth shows his appreciation of the Australian countryside as he shows the landscape, forests, shorelines and features around him. At times. Kenneth himself appears in the reel on the other side of camera. When at Wilson’s Promontary the footage indicates the style of camping at the time: individual cabins alongside shared facilities likely to have included bathrooms, kitchen and laundry and recreation rooms. Kenneth also shows the old goldtown of Walhalla with its deserted atmosphere. The last part of the reel shows a waterski regatta and speed boats on Albert Park Lake in Melbourne.

Selected highlights list:

(No title)
00:00:00:00 to 00:00:27:00 distant views and roads on the way though what we will come to know is Gippsland.

00:00:32:00 ‘Wilson’s Promontory’ sign, posted alongside the Darby Bridge, its sign and Bob Wootton standing on the bridge.

00:00:38:00 Kenneth Rankine himself looking out over the Darby River.

00:00:45:00 to 00:01:40:00 views of the sea over low lying hills followed by shots of teatree, country roads leading down to the sea, views of the coastline, rocky hills and flower shots.

00:01:42:00 ‘Tidal River’ camping grounds. Just before departing the Prom, there is a lovely view of what appears to be Norman Bay near Tidal River.

00:02:04:00 a sign for ‘Port Welshpool’ followed by views of an estuary at low tide, several piers and fishing boats.

00:02:36:00 a fisherman appears (as indicated by thigh high galoshes) walking along a pier and chatting to Bob Wootton.

00:03:01:00 a sign for the ‘Balook Private Hotel Excellent Accommodation’.

00:03:28:00 after more hillsides and views we see a sign for ‘Bulga Park Shire of Alberton’ (which existed 1855 to 1994; currently Shire of Wellington).

00:04:28:00 sign for Tarra Valley Park appears. In this footage Kenneth has gone to some trouble to capture the Parks, framing his shots of waterfalls, ferns and trees through bracken fronds, branches or rope walks to create a lush feel.

00:06:32 the Corrigan Suspension (walk) Bridge. Shortly after, we are looking down on the Thomson River. Kenneth includes several shots of bridges including the first from which he takes footage of the river below.

00:07:02:00 perhaps foot bridge evident by the scratched initials on the railing. Rail and road bridges are shot from different angles from 00:06:48 to 00:07:02:00.

00:07:10:00 Walhalla Post Office; some deserted and derelict buildings, a shop sign for ‘Agent of the State Savings Bank Guaranteed by the Government of Victoria’ on the door of a derelict Teashop, the Walhalla Station sign on a building which houses old carts with a shot of ‘1903’ on one of the carts, elaborate stone walls.

00:08:11:00 a working timber mill. There are more shots of overgrown brick remnants of buildings in the steep hillsides, rail tracks and old cars.

00:08:41:00 Bob Wootton works a rail lever to move the old tracks. Kenneth has taken views of the town that reflect the almost abandoned state of Walhalla at the time, following the end of the gold mining boom and after the ‘Black Friday’ bushfires that ravaged the State in 1939.

00:08:54:00 program for the ‘A Speedboat and Water - Ski Regatta assisted by the Sirocco Cherokee and Yarrawonga Water Ski Clubs’, held at Albert Park Lake (Melbourne) in 1956. Footage of speedboat racing on the lake follows.

00:10:21:00 a helicopter is filmed flying and hovering overhead.

00:10:30:00 men water skiing; good examples of male swimming trunks. A largish crowd of onlookers and several lakeside buildings.

00:11:37:00 ski jumps.

00:12:40:00 footage of an early display of kitesurfing.

results.title: Blinky Bill production featurette
results.brief_description: Documentary capturing the production process behind the creation of a Blinky Bill animated film. Includes storyboard and cel animation, sound recording, filming live action footage, creating models, music composition and sound recording.Yoram Gross, John Palmer (writer), Frank Hammond (cinematographer), Ray Nowland (art director), Guy Gross (composer) and other crew are also featured discussing their work.

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 33]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

This film shows various moments in the Anderson family, including kids’ birthday parties, beach holidays and First Communion at the church. There is some great footage of fashion in the 1960s, particularly beach wear.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 a birthday party, kids eating cake and wearing paper hats
00:01:08:00 a boy blowing vigorously on a party horn
00:02:00:00 birthday boy receiving his gift, a Tommy Thunder toy machine gun
00:02:33:00 girl with fake vampire teeth
00:03:01:00 people sunbaking on the beach
00:04:03:00 the three boys learning to swim
00:05:47:00 snow or hail on the streets of Ballarat, driving through the storm
00:06:12:00 kids on toy bikes and pushing a dog in a pram
00:07:45:00 rows of children in matching outfits at church
00:08:25:00 learning to ride a bike
00:10:30:00 First Communion at church with all the girls in white dresses and veils
00:11:57:00 an older couple walking down the street
00:13:00:00 boys in party hats
00:13:40:00 birthday cakes and frog in a pond (chocolate frog in jelly)
00:14:45:00 more relaxed sunbaking on the beach
00:15:16:00 the three boys in matching bathers (swimwear)
00:15:47:00 picnic under a large red beach umbrella
00:16:42:00 boy in yellow terry towelling hat enjoying a can of Fanta
00:18:55:00 group of kids exploring on the beach and throwing food to seagulls
00:21:03:00 on the slide at local playground

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 33]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film introduces the third Wootton child. Of particular note are the examples of hand made and hand knitted clothing worn by the children.

Selected highlights list:
(No title)
00:00:00:00 to 00:14:00:00 introduction of a third child to the Wootton family, with the three children sitting in the garden on the outdoor cane chairs very typical of the era; the older two children are showing their growing confidence in front of the camera.

00:02:11:00 we see a shot of the family in formal clothes , typical of the ‘Sunday best’ way of dressing and posing for photographs at the time.

00:02:40:00 to 00:02:59:00 shows the now toddler’s first steps to confident running around the lawn.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

In this film, titled ‘Our Garden’, Kenneth introduces us to the Rankine house (exterior) and garden as well as family and friends meeting and greeting the camera, playing ball games, showing off the family pet rabbit and dog and finally. This reel also introduces Bob Wootton who will marry daughter Bettye Rankine. Kenneth includes lingering shots of flowers which often feature throughout his films, often to separate his scenes. There are some great examples of the style and textiles of the clothes of the era and the family cars that feature in Kenneth’s reels. As proof that Bob Wootton is now in the family, Kenneth directs a kiss between him and his future mother-in-law to end the reel.

Selected highlights list:

00:04:12:00 women of the house posing in matching frocks and dodging bees where Kenneth has them pose.

00:04:27:00 the women eating watermelon.

00:04:54:00 one of the women wearing a uniform (possible of the WAAAF).

00:06:30:00 example of 1940 style dress with gloves and bag.
00:07:04:00 another uniform shot interspersed with flowers and the pet rabbit.

00:08:51:00 fruit trees are another feature of the garden and whilst collecting apricots, apples and green beans we see some examples of two piece sunsuits of the day.

00:14:11:00 title card ‘Peter’ begins a sequence featuring the family pet rabbit.

00:16:18:00 shows Mrs Rankine in a large black car in the driveway before shots of the lawns covered in hailstones or sleet.

00:16:31:00 title card ‘Kim’ introduces us to the family dog and to a young Bob Wootton who would become part of the family when married to Kenneth’s daughter.

00:17:30:00 title card ‘His First Bath’ shows the dog being washed in two enamel bowls typical of the time.

00:18:36:00 car being driven by Bob Wootton and members of the family in or near the car and playing with Kim.

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 15]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film presents scenes of families on holidays at the beach and the snow, along with suburban backyard activities,children’s parties, and some interesting glimpses of country Victoria in the 1970s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:48:00 exterior scenes of ski lodge with children in front
00:01:13:00 children snowball play
00:01:23:00 exterior shot of Mt. Buller landscape from lodge balcony
00:01:49:00 shot of lodge exterior with “Crosscut Lodge” sign
00:01:59:00 children skiing downhill
00:02:10:00 children catching a “stand-up” ski lift pole
00:02:29:00 close-up of 70s ski fashion
00:02:52:00 warm colours and well-lit fashion on ski slope
00:03:02:00 sit down ski lift
00:03:13:00 good close-up shot of man and child catching a seated ski lift; man wearing fashionable sunglasses from the era
00:03:25:00 some nice tracking shots taken while on the ski lift
00:03:53:00 man and child on ski lift – 70s fashion and hair
00:04:36:00 backyard children’s birthday party with costumes, balloons, bikes, trampoline, party, games
00:04:56:00 musical chairs and pass the parcel outside
00:05:47:00 backyard cricket
00:06:05:00 close-up women’s 70s fashion
00:06:14:00 purple Ford Fairlane in front yard with BP sign in the background
00:06:21:00 nice close-up of Ford Fairlane
00:06:32:00 children eating BBQ
00:06:43:00 child playing and jumping with “Space Hopper”
00:08:08:00 street parade with child riding a bike while in blackface – Ballarat 1974
00:08:39:00 interesting filming from inside a marching band while marching in parade
00:11:25:00 slow-motion reverse footage of kids falling “IN” to a rubber dingy from water
00:11:45:00 interesting moving shot of seagulls jumping from a pier
00:12:28:00 nice shot of child eating pastie and drinking Coke in front of old Sorrento front beach kiosk
00:14:03:00 nice beach scene with colourful umbrella and 70s beach fashion

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film contains scenes taken of the Rankine/Wootton children, filmed primarily at play in a garden. We see the children grow as the film tracks their growth over 3 years. Kenneth uses shots of flowers, trees and leaves throughout to separate scenes.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:10:00 title card “Now I am 3 & Look at Elizabeth 9 months”.

00:00:49:00 baby Elizabeth wearing a hat while sitting strapped into a coach-built pram.

00:01:27:00 family picnic, complete with picnic rug, wicker baskets, thermos flasks and folding chairs.

00:02:14:00 children in the garden shows us excellent examples of hand made and hand knitted children’s clothes. The images of Elizabeth at play show what fun small children can have with just a cardboard box.

00:03:52:00 close-up of a butterfly on foliage.

00:04:47:00 the children have grown and the eldest child is off to school as shown by his schoolbag. The Reel ends with a close-up of dad and the kids.

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 35]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

This film shows various scenes of life in the Anderson family, including the kids riding a dirt bike, holidays at the beach, and birthday parties.

Selected highlights list:

00:02:03:00 all the kids taking turns on the new Honda dirt bike

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

Films aren’t just for entertainment – they can document experiences, transport us to other worlds or act as windows into the past. The home movie collection of amateur filmmaker Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890–1968) is all three.

Did you know that there was an outdoor Olympic pool across the train tracks from where Fed Square now sits in the 40s? How about the high-octane car race the Templestowe Hill Climb, which snaked through 960 metres of outer suburb scrub?

Thanks to Kenneth’s granddaughter, who donated his films to our collection in August 2016, we can peer back into Melbourne’s past, sharing everyday and extraordinary experiences.

Comprising 38 cans of silent, colour 16mm films, Kenneth’s collection portrays gardens, regional and interstate holidays, beauty pageants, shipping ports, water skiing and royal visits, many of the films introduced by his custom-made title, “KenRa Films Present”. No surprise for a celluloid enthusiast who had a movie studio behind his Caulfield home.

Kenneth even came third in a Western Australian amateur film competition for Every Many Should Have A Hobby, a fictional narrative of a man pursuing his secret filmmaking passion. The film is currently undergoing conservation treatment due to acetate deterioration, but we’re hoping to get it digitised like the wonderful home movies in this collection.
